newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Arafat says rejects Israel demand for crackdown.
newsitem.headline: Arafat says rejects Israel demand for crackdown.

text.p: Palestinian President Yasser Arafat said on Saturday he would not bow to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's demand he crack down on militants in the aftermath of July's double suicide attack.
"We reject any dictates or any conditions," Arafat told reporters in the West Bank town of Nablus when asked about Netanyahu's demand. "He (Netanyahu) should know who he is talking to."
The Palestinian leader blasted Israeli sanctions imposed after last month's bombings which killed 16 people in an Israeli market, including the two attackers.

"There is an attempt to steal money from the VAT and taxes that belong to the Palestinian people," Arafat said, referring to Netanyahu's freezing of financial transfers Israel owes the Palestinian Authority under a 1994 economic protocol.
The United States said on Friday it was disappointed at Israel's delay in releasing funds to the Authority.

"(U.S. envoy Dennis) Ross said that there are measures done by Israel outside the security framework that have no relation to security. He tried to reach solutions with the Israelis but had no results," Arafat said.
